name: Evening Primrose Oil
summary: Evening primrose oil (EPO) is a plant-based supplement rich in gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), an omega-6 fatty acid believed to support skin health, reduce inflammation, and potentially improve mood and premenstrual symptoms.
description: Evening primrose oil is extracted from the seeds of the evening primrose plant (Oenothera biennis). It contains gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), a precursor to anti-inflammatory prostaglandins. EPO has been studied for a wide range of conditions, including eczema, mastalgia, premenstrual syndrome (PMS), menopause-related symptoms, and mood regulation. While evidence is mixed, some studies suggest benefits for women’s health and mild anti-inflammatory effects. It is widely available as an over-the-counter dietary supplement.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved as a drug)

items: Relief of PMS and cyclical mastalgia
Support for eczema and dry skin

sections.text: Evening primrose oil provides gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), which is converted into dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (DGLA). DGLA is a precursor to anti-inflammatory prostaglandins (PGE1), which may help modulate hormonal fluctuations, reduce breast pain, and improve skin barrier function.

adult.typical: 500–2000 mg per day, divided into 1–2 doses
adult.note: Standardized to contain 8–10% GLA; clinical studies often use 240–320 mg of GLA daily.

sections.pediatric: Not commonly used in children; consult healthcare provider.

sections.text: Benefits may take 4–12 weeks of consistent use, especially for skin conditions and PMS.

other: May increase bleeding risk if combined with anticoagulants or antiplatelet medications.
Use caution in individuals with epilepsy or seizure history.

sections.pregnancy: Possibly unsafe in late pregnancy; may increase bleeding or induce uterine contractions
sections.lactation: Limited data; likely safe in small amounts
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe with caution for bleeding risk

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: Most studied for mastalgia and PMS; effects are modest but may benefit some individuals.
Clinical evidence for eczema is mixed, with stronger benefit noted in small subgroups.
Works synergistically with omega-3 fatty acids to balance inflammatory pathways.
